reviews.review_text: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a 3rd person shooter based in the (suprise!) 40k universe. I've played several Warhammer 40,000 video games. Some were good, others mediocre, and others were so great that I still play them, even several years after their release.  This is one of them.  This is one of the best 40k games, period. It nails everything- from what makes a good 3rd person shooter, to what makes a true-to-lore 40k game.   To start off, This isn't your standard 3rd person-totally-not-gears-of-war game. Whilst most 3PSs focus on a cover system, Space Marine removes that entirely. You ARE the cover. You can wade into a mob of enemies, without dying every 3 seconds. It perfectly encapsulates what makes a space marine a space marine, and lets you experience that firsthand.  The combat is divided into two parts- ranged and melee. You are given a wide variety of weapons to slaughter your enemies in different and uniquely brutal ways. Each weapon feels (and sounds!) exactly how it should. The shot of a bolter, the hiss of a meltagun, and the roar of a plasma cannon. And although the ranged weapons are cool, the melee weapons are even better. Chainswords (chainsaw-swords) evicerate and rend flesh whenever they strike, turning a large horde of orks into a bloody mess very quickly. Thunder hammers, although slow, deal tremendous damage and completly pulverise your enemies. The combat (especially in single player or the horde-mode) is immensly satisfying and one of the best parts of the game.  The game has both a single-player and a multiplayer. The single player has a decently lengthy campaign (10-12 hours) with a pretty good story. It does have its faults (unfinished story arcs that will probably never get finished b/c r.i.p THQ), and the last boss fight is pretty lame. The multiplayer, although good and reasonably well balanced, gets repedative with the 4 maps (excluding expansions). You also can't choose which side you are on pre-match, meaning you might not even get to see your shiny new color scheme for a couple matches. The multiplayer also follows the standard 'level up to improve' philosophy, with special perks unlocked by completing challenges (some of which are brutally difficult without help).   Overall, this is a fantastic 40k game that really makes you feel like you are playing a space marine. It has a few issues (mostly with multiplayer), but you can easily get many hours of enjoyment out of this game.

I really hope relic get another chance with this IP, I would love to see a sequel.

One of the most fun single player campaigns I've played in a hack and slash game ever, even more so if you already enjoy the W40K universe. Gameplay is solid with a decent challenge given and intuitive controls. Though not overly difficult, it is still challenging enough that you feel satisfied when you manage to gun down or hack apart the few hundred orks blocking the way to your objective. The devs have done an amazing job with the weapons. Bolters sound and feel exactly like they should when firing rounds into mobs of Greenskins, while ripping them apart with your chainsword is equally satisfying, visually and audibly. For me though nothing beats flying around in a jetpack, thunder hammer in hand, crushing heads into the cement. The rest of the game as far as atmosphere and overall feel goes is supurb, really feels like a Warhammer game and won't leave you disappointed. Storywise the game is nothing mindblowingly original as far as W40K goes but it does keep you interested until the end. Originally meant to be a trilogy, THQ went bankrupt before they managed to make the sequels so we don't ever get to find out what happened to Captain Titus, but even so it's worth playing for the story if you're a fan of the lore. The multiplayer was fun back in the day but is completely dead now so don't get this if that's what you're looking for. I wouldn't say the replay value of this game is especially high, but I enjoyed it enough the first time through to eventually play it again a couple more times, and probably will again in the future, though your mileage may vary. If you're a Warhammer 40K fan or just of hack and slash games in general, I'd say definitely give Space Marine a go, especially when it goes on sale if you're still unsure. When I first heard about this game, I wanted it. I was finally getting an action game from Warhammer instead of a typical RTS that usually happens with Warhammer games. I bounced up and down in joy, I flew across the room and hit my face against a door. In happiness.  But anyways, I was a huge fan of the Warhammer games, and I wanted this game. I picked it up during the 2012 Christmas Sale, and haven't regretted it once. It's one of the few games where I go back and play it after finishing the game. I loved this game, so much. The gameplay involves you slicing orks, stomping a body and making it explode, removing limbs entirely, and just for lack of trying, you can blow their heads off. With a sword. It's one of the few games where it combines melee and ranged combat fairly seamlessly (There are a few holes here and there.), where it makes you feel like neither the melee or the ranged is overpowering the other. I played through the campaign, where I was expecting to just use melee, but that was not the case. I ended up using a variety of ranged weapons to get through the game.  The healing system is rather interesting for this game. You have shields that regenerate out of combat (Like in Halo, for lack of a better comparison.) but your health doesn't regen out of combat. You have to do special kill moves to regenerate health. These can include shoving a chainsword through an Ork's body then moving it upwards and removing pretty much their entire spinal cord. They can also include exploding an ork's face. With your foot. There are some things that could be changed though to make it a more enjoyable experience. For example, you regain the health after the kill move, and you can be killed during the animation. There's no way to cancel the move, but for the most part this doesn't get in the way too much.  This game really made me feel like I could take on an entire horde of Orks by myself and come out barely scratched. I also did that in the game. However, it has a checkpoint system that could be vastly improved. Or at least make cutscenese that you can skip. They stick a checkpoint before an unskippable cutscene then shove you into a fight you could die fairly quickly in, and you have to watch the cutscene again. That's one of the only design flaws.  When I heard there weren't going to be anymore games after this, I was super bummed. I was hoping for Space Marine sequels even after THQ died. And then I read an article saying it had been canceled. Even if we didn't get any sequels, we got an amazing first game.  In short, I loved it. This is one of my most favorite games of all time.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a third-person shooter set in the universe of Warhammer 40,000 that follows one captain of the Ultramarines, Titus, on his mission on the Forge World Graia, which is under heavy attack by a Ork horde seeking to posses the powerful weapons built in the planet's factories. Later in the game, Titus and his two accompanying Ultramarines, Sidonus and Leandros, must also face the threat of a Chaos Warband lead by a dangerous Chaos sorcerer named Nemeroth.  The main beef of Space Marine's gameplay is using the weapons you are given tocut through the hordes of enemies preventing you from advancing and then proceed in the levels. You are given both long ranged weapons (like pistols or sniper rifles) and close quarters tools (starting from a chainsaw and arriving at a huge electrified mallet): you must learn to switch between the two constantly, given you'll face various kinds of enemies (some of them dangerous on the long distances while others extremely weak if chopped down in close combat). Each weapon has different versions that are unlocked advancing in the game, each with its pros and cons. On top of his health pool, Titus can take advantage of a recharging shield that can protect him against some of the enemy fire and a super mode of some sort: the mode is charged by dishing out damage and, whenever unleashed, allows you to recover health over time and aim at enemies in slow-motion. Finishing enemies when they are weak also allows you to boost your health.  The main campaign is extremely faithful to the Warhammer 40,000 universe, both in design of the environments and characters and the references made to the general lore of the series. It lasts for aboutsix or eight hours or so and, aside from fighting your way through Graia, you can find hidden servo-skulls bearing audio recordings that further expand the game's story. There are three different difficulties (easy, normal and hard), but I'd say that even the normal mode manages to be challenging enough.  Warhammer 40,00: Space Marine also spots a rather interesting multiplayer mode. You can either play as a Space Marine or a Chaos Marine, and the game offers a customization menu that allows you to deeply personalize your marine (armor pieces, colours, insigna, ...). The multiplayer mode offers several game modes, the same you could expect into a big retail multiplayer shooter: capture the flag, capture the control point, ... The mode also features co-op missions. The player actually makes progress in multiplayer thanks to a level system, unlocking new armor pieces and/or weapons and perks as he/she gains more experience. As I'm writing this review and four years after the game's release, Space Marine's multiplayer is still really populated.  Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine, along with the Dawn of War series, is a great example about how a complex series like Warhammer 40,000 can be boiled down in a rather charming game capable of offering a great time both to the fans of the series and newcommers just wanting to enjoy some good third-person shooting action

The metacritic rating for Space Marine is about right (74%), but I thoroughly enjoyed it because the developers painstakingly recreated the 40k universe. I don't think I know if another franchise-based game that feels quite as spot on. With that said, the gameplay does have a few issues. Combat borrows heavily from God of War, with the addition of a solid shooter component (sans cover mechanic, thankfully?); which is to say the combat has variety but lacks real depth. Multiplayer has serious ups and downs, due mostly to the lack of dedicated server support and MASSIVE lag issues if the host is not on your content (which happens about half of the time). The 'unlocks' and leveling component offers a few gameplay options without breaking multiplayer. Also included is a co-op 'survival' mode (up to 4 players), which only has a few maps but is a riot when you can pull together a few buds for a match. When Space Marine is on sale, it's a great buy for any Warhammer 40k fan.

First of all, I'm a big fan of Warhammer 40k setting, tabletop games and PC strategy games; I LOVED the possibility of playing in an action game based in this universe: being a Space Marine, saving Imperial Guardsmen, meeting Inquisitors and defeating Chaos. I hoped it was good. I WANTED it to be good.  ...however, this game is AWFUL.  What we've got here is a boring, linear, repetitive third person action/shooter game. Every area is structured as an 'arena' where you'll fight endless hordes of Orks (with a little variation in the last hours) with no strategy, timing or ability involved.  Again and again. And again. These fights will be EXTREMELY easy, except for some difficulty spikes thrown randomly into the game. When you die you never feel like it was your fault, nor you feel to improve your abilities when you defeat 10 or 15 'Ard Boyz.  Then there's the setting. Every ambient has no details and is identical to the one before and to the next one, meaning you'll be frequently lost and looking for an exit. There's no map, but don't worry: once you've reached an area you won't be able to go back to the previous one, meaning that exploration is absolutely useless. Moreover, you don't get any strategic benefit from the environment, except for some explosive barrels or crates of ammo & granades once in a while, so why bother?  In the end, this game was a huge disappointment for me. Go buy it ONLY if you know and love Warhammer 40k lore and the only thing you want to do for the next 15 hours is press X on your controller. Like me you might have heard people say that it gets repetative after a while and though i do agree that the gameplay or gameplay mechanics are quite straight forward and not very versatile it did not bother me all that much. Just like with both the Cybertron games in the Transformers franchise the gameplay is fairly solid and that didn't seem to affect the scores that those titles got. I never got quite enough of grabbing yet another Ork and ripping his head off or curbing him with my massive space boots.  The expansive scenery keeps changing every so many chapters and so do the enemies and this does keep you interested. Especially the massive outdoor areas were impressive to walk around in. Massive bridges in the backround, hundreds of space crafts flying over head, a level build around a giant mech that you eventually will have to board, it all feels very grand and you really feel a part of it all. All this plus solid visuals and an entertaining storyline kept me going in wanting to finish my heroic mission in trying to save the planet.  You could finish the game in one go in i'd say roughly 6 to 8 hours or so which maybe not all that much but it's enough that it satisfies. Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine.  This game is great in so many ways from the rich atmosphere and storyline. However if you want a great story driven singleplayer campaign revolving around Space marines 'Hulking human beings in even hulkier semi indestructable power armor fighting age old enemies in a near unwinnable war to save their race' then look no further. But if multiplayer/pvp is your desire Then I'd say look away.  Now the multiplayer isn't well... dead? necessarily, But it sure as hell isn't all that alive. Lets say for the most part it's a zombie and not in a good way. (If there is a good way with zombies) No you can for all extensive purposes get into a multiplayer match sadly though you may end up regretting it.   Currently you can only really ever find a pvp match in the most popular game mode 'Seize ground' where all the others are empty.(for the most part)   And when you find a server the game is player hosted from litterally all around the globe. Meaning the host may be in china japan or more commonly russia. (For steamers in russia multiplayer may be alive and kicking)   when you try to connect from halfway accross the world to the only match being hosted the results will have you mad all to hell when you smash an afk guy in the face with a hammer twice! after unloading two pistol clips and a grenade into him only to have him unscathed un-afk and kill you with a single shot from a shotgun-esque heatraygun seconds later.....(ARE YOU ♥♥♥♥ING KIDDING ME RIGHT NOW!)   Now that's not to say multiplayer wasnt fun. Like when I found a good server I was all 'Goody gumdrops batman! did ya see me chainsword that guys head off?! I mean holy ♥♥♥♥ when multiplayer connections in this game were equal it was... euphoric. But you just don't find any games like that anymore. Or if you do they're so few and far between that you'll already be exausted with the game by the time you find one. (my experience)  However for multiplayer in the co-operative game mode 'Exterminatus' witch is pretty much some of the most fun you can have. Really the issue I have with this game is it's multiplayer and to be honest the singleplayer campaign may be enough that I should give a positive review. But I just can't. CONS:  -Non dedicated multiplayer servers  -Player hosted multiplayer (Causes severe lag)  -Lag (You will unload multiple clips on someone just to have them kill you in 1 blow)  -Nearly no playerbase (Hard to find a game, youll be playing 1 game mode in multiplayer)  -Player animation slow down glitch (Forces character to slow down when running/walking for no reason)    As always these are just my views. I've seen the board game. I didn't like it. I thought the characters looked cartoonish and even in this video game they were odd looking. I didn't have high hopes for this game but I thought I would try it out anyway.  Playing it...it was like the game walked up to me, looked me in the eye, slapped me and told me to shut my big fat face.  The game is good!  This isn't the typical 3rd person shooter. In many scenarios you need to think of where you need to move to, stand at, take cover behind...what type of weapon would work best... You just cannot take the approach of 'charge in and kill everything'. You actually need to think. By the second half of the game you will get used to switching weapons in battle to match the conditions. You will also be using grenades regularly. Unlike in a alot of games where I never had to use them at all to finish the game. BTW, for those who are asking on the myriad of boards.... The Vengeance launcher. When you fire you can detonate the bomb by pressing 'R'. If you fire five, the sixth will detonate the oldest bomb in play. If you shoot and hit the bomb with a firearm, that too will set it off. But really, pressing 'R' is the easiest.   Also, there are no 'health items' in this game. At the end/start of certain scenarios you are healed. But in every other part of the game you have to excecute someone to heal or use the rage and hit/shoot people to heal. At first, I thought this was strange. But the game mechanic of it is actually quite appealing. It makes you work to stay alive and not just gobble up potions or etc...  The first thing you will notice about the game is that there is no jumping. Pressing the spacebar only makes you combat roll. At first this ticked me off. But, after playing for a bit, it made sense in the game universe. They are wearing advanced versions of big, heavy and bulky medieval armor. So of course they can't jump. That is why they have the jet packs.  The second thing you will notice is that there isn't the fake, ultra fast reloads you see in most games. Reloading takes a bit of time. It really makes you pay attention to your weapon and switch or use your melee weapon. With your melee weapon you can have various combos depending on which one you pick up. This was kind of a fun thing for me to try out to emulate fighting games.  The third thing...thankfully...is skippable cutscenes. If you've seen it once why watch it again? Unlike in some games I've played here on Steam where you cannot skip the cutscenes...being able to is always a plus and always something I will mention in order to get game makers in the habit of doing so.  Fourth...I had no in game crashes, stutters, drop in FPS or bugs. Insert a choir of angels singing 'Hellelujah!'   Fifth, this is not open world and it will pretty much funnel you from point 'A' to point 'B'. This wasn't so bad as the battles you would envariably encounter didn't feel repetative. The game designers did a FANTASTIC job of varying the opponents and creating different environments in order to get you to do things differently otherwise you would die.  Lastly... I will leave the finer points of the game to the other, better, reviewers on here. But to wrap it up. This game was GOOD. Maybe not great. But definitely worth the money even if it isn't on sale. Will I replay it? Probably not. But the first run through was good so I would very much consider it. Even if not, I will leave this game with good memories of it and a feeling of satisfaction in playing it.

A surprisingly fun game. I would describe the gameplay as similar to Gears of War, but with less emphasis on cover and more options for melee.   The 40K universe is brought to life in this game, and it's as violently beautiful as you'd expect. Heads are popped off by bullets and smaller Orks can be shoulder-bashed into nothing. The game encourages you to make violent melee executions as they are the only way to regain health during a heated battle. The game starts off as facing down the Ork horde until the late-game stages, when the focus suddenly shifts to the powers of Chaos, which are a good deal harder. This is a game that really deserves a sequel.   One thing I would note about this game (in my experience at least) is that it can be quite awkward to play with a keyboard and mouse, I would recommend a controller for the smoothest experience.
